Hosting your Ghost Content on GitHub.io

14 June 2019 on ghost, web, blog

When I set out to create my technical writing portfolio, I knew that I would be eventually hosting from my GitHub repository using GitHub Pages. And I knew that I wanted to keep the same awesome writing environment I'd enjoyed with Medium.com â€“ so using Ghost to management my content was an obvious choice for me.

But I didn't stop to think about how I'd convert my data from Ghost posts to utilize the free static site hosting service on my GitHub page. After all, Ghost uses a local MySQL database to store its content and must be deployed by a managed web service running Node.js. Â But GitHub pages isn't a fully robust virtual server - it's a simple web service that can only deploy posts and pages as static HTML files.

So my options were a bit restricted my own choosiness

First of all, I couldn't Host the Ghost engine the official Ghost(Pro) managed service because I need the content to be built as static files to use for GitHub Pages.

The first time I set up a Ghost site, I simply configured a LAMP droplet at DigtialOcean and administrator the deployments through my virtual server. Â This worked well for a while, but hosting costs became a huge factor. Especially during earlier development and administration; each update to your settings or content is going to use resources on the virtual server and this starts to add up over time. Â And even then, similar to GhostPro, I still need to somehow build the files to HTML. Â At this point, there seemed to be no advantage to hosting the engine using a fully fledged web server.

So there I thought was only one option to choose:

  • Host the Ghost engine locally and convert the files to static HTML Â 

This was an attractive option, but I became a little paralyzed as I looked at my static generation options. Jekyll, Gatsby, Hugo, Gridsome â€“ ugh, how much skin does this cat have?

I searched a little about how other's tackle this problem and while Ghost API is very well documented and easy for me to use with other projects, I felt it was a bit overkill to spend time setting up a static site framework to host a handful of markdown files that were already built as a web page in my local environment anyway!

So, deciding to stick solely with Ghost, I also came across out-of-date utilities that supposedly helped with this problem by downloading the pages to simply throw on a web server, which seemed like both a straightforward and a puzzling solution to me â€“ why do I need another utility? Â The web pages already work in my browser locally. Â And my experience doing QA/Support for public ISPs and hosting providers made me comfortable using the standard wget utility to download web pages, files, and images from the web using the command line, and is essentially what these other utilities were doing. Â 

Through late-night trial and error with wget, I was able to easily build and commit the entire website you see today. Â And then after I had to go back and retrace my steps, I thought more attention could be given to the solution, so here I am writing to you.

Setting Up Ghost Local

I'll keep this part brief, but should be enough to help get ghost running local for you to play if you've never used it before.

1. Install Node.js

Download and install the latest Node version from their official website.

2. Install Ghost CLI (command line tool)

Using npm package manager, open your terminal and execute the following commands to install the latest ghost CLI 

$ sudo npm install -g ghost-cli@latest

3. Install Ghost locally using command line tool

Wherever you'd like your local host to reside, create an empty folder for your site to install Ghost, e.g.,

$ mkdir ghost-blog

Now, navigate into the ghost-blog folder and install local version of ghost.

$ ghost install local

Wait for the installation to complete and ghost will be automatically started in your terminal.

When Ghost is running, you'll be able to preview a copy of your site using the theme you chose when you access the admin interface. Â This environment is going to be your little "sandbox" where you can stage and preview your site before you upload files to GitHub.

THE WGET COMMAND

Generally speaking, if you simply need a way to request a static version of any hosted document, then you just need to use wget to download your files locally. Assuming your local ghost site looks perfect (and I assure you, it does), you'll be ready to download your site using wget and upload it to GitHub.

Running the following command from your terminal will download a static copy of each file linked in the URL and can be parameterized to ensure all your content and links work the same as hosted at the development version:

$ wget -r -nH -P dist -E -k localhost:port

Let's break down this command

(each option is cAse seNsiTiVe)

  • wget: a standard utility for fetching web site data from the command line. Â If you're using mac or linux, you probably have this installed by default. Â If not, it's pretty straightforward to ... uh, get.
  • -r: we're instructing wget to download files in a recursive manner â€“ meaning wget will first requested the primary document at the given URL (http://localhost:2368/), and then download each local document linked. Â This makes sure we get all the referenced libraries, style sheets, important children pages linked in the site.
  • -nH: disables host-prefixed file names (no need to include localhost in output file name).
  • -P: gets all files, including images so the desired document looks just like you published.
  • dist: the relative folder you wish to output the contents.
  • -E: adds HTML/CSS extension to the destination file type.
  • -k: ensures links are converted to local files.
  • localhost:port: Â the default location of your ghost install is usually http://localhost:2368.
Tip: Â I'm using port 2500, but your configuration is probably different â€“ the port your ghost instance is running should be listed when you start ghost with ghost start. Â If you have issues, check your ghost directory config.development.json for your project's port value.

When the command finishes

You will see your links converted relative to the folder used in the command (should be in a folder named dist if you used my example above). Â Each "post" or "page" will be organized in a unique folder and contain an index.html file for each.

Since these are local and static HTML links, you can open any of the index.html files generated and open them directly in your browser to preview. If there are errors, use your browser developer tools to debug them, and check that all of your links and extension are set properly.

Conclusion

You can now host your static Ghost content to your https://pages.github.com account! Â After your push to the master branch, your Project Pages site will be available at http(s)://<username>.github.io/<projectname>. Â 

Check out GitHub Pages Basics for help deploying to your pages.
